document.docTitle: Winnertzia silvestris Jaschhof & Jaschhof 2020, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Reevaluation of species richness in Winnertzia (Diptera, Cecidomyiidae, Winnertziinae), with descriptions of 37 new species from Sweden, Peru and Australia

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Reevaluation of species richness in Winnertzia (Diptera, Cecidomyiidae, Winnertziinae), with descriptions of 37 new species from Sweden, Peru and Australia

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. Males of this species can be recognized using the following characters in combination. The length of the eye bridge matches 4–5 lateral and 1–2 dorsal ommatidia; the neck of the fourth flagellomere is 1.1 times as long as the node ( Figs 124–125 ); the apical segment of the palpus is longer than each of the three preceding segments; pronotal setae number 9–17, anepimeral setae 5–9; the lateral mediotergal microtrichia are only little enlarged; the fore tibia is shorter than the second tarsomere (length ratio tb/T 2 = 0.8; Fig. 127 ); and the empodia are half as long as the claws whose basal tooth is as large as that usually found in
Winnertzia
( Fig. 126 ). As regards genitalic characters ( Jaschhof & Jaschhof 2013 : fig. 45A), the posterior edge of the ninth tergite is perfectly sinuous; the gonocoxal emargination, which is smaller than that of
W. pratensis
, extends only slightly beyond the midlength of the gonocoxal synsclerite; and the gonostylus has a conspicuously steep-walled apex. Additionally, males of
W. silvestris
are on average larger (1.5–2.0 mm) than that of
W. pratensis
( 1.4–1.6 mm ), a closely related species described above. Females and preimaginal stages of
W. silvestris
are unknown.

Etymology. The Latin adjective
silvestris
translates as forest-dwelling, referring to the habitat in which all our specimens were collected.

Type material.
Holotype .
Male , Sweden , Uppland , Uppsala , Fiby Nature Reserve , swampy section of oldgrowth mixed hemiboreal forest,
9 June–23 July 2010
, Malaise trap , M. & C. Jaschhof (spn GULI000020956 in NHRS )
.
Paratypes .
1 male , Sweden , Skåne , Simrishamn , Stenshuvud National Park , old-growth mixed broadleaf forest,
16 June 2009
, sweepnet, MCJ (spn GULI000020955 in NHRS )
;
1 male , Uppland, Knivsta, Rickebasta NR , swamp forest of alder interspersed with spruce trees,
1–27 August 2009
, MT , MCJ
(spn SE 1655 in SDEI )
.

Other material studied.
Sweden : 1 male , Öland , Mörbylånga , Färjestaden , backyard with grove of young birches,
10 June–10 July 2015
, MT , MCJ (spn CEC 3054 in SDEI )
;
1 male , Småland , Nybro , Bäckebo , Grytsjön NR , old-growth mixed hemiboreal forest,
17 June–16 July 2015
, MT , MCJ (spn CEC 3053 in SDEI )
.

Distribution and phenology. The five specimens known of
W. silvestris
were collected in summer (June–August) in different woodlands in the southern half of Sweden ( Skåne to Uppland).

Previous literature on Cecidomyiidae poorly demonstrates the extraordinary species richness in
Winnertzia
as revealed by the present study. While our survey recorded 93 different
Winnertzia
from a single Northern European country, a total of 97 species had previously been named from throughout the world. This imbalance tempts one to speculate on the size of the genus, a detail that can help design similar studies in the future. We think that our work in Sweden was intense enough to record all common and widespread Winnertzi a, but we certainly missed quite a number of rare species, including those inhabiting small ranges or narrow ecological niches. While applying standard entomological methods for collecting specimens for study, we did not test the efficiency of devices targeting potential larval habitats, such as ground and tree photoeclectors. Also, the presumptively discrete species subsumed under
W. solidaginis
are not counted in our census total. For those reasons we regard our inventory as incomplete and estimate that the Swedish fauna is likely to contain 120–150 species of
Winnertzia
. This in turn suggests the presence of 300–400
Winnertzia
species in all of Europe, 500–800 in the Palearctic region, and
2,000 –3,000 in
the world. With that,
Winnertzia
might be the largest genus of mycophagous gall midges. We have to admit here that hard data to back those estimates are scarce, although some supporting evidence was provided by the ZADBI Project, which found 39 different
Winnertzia
, all unnamed, occurring at a single site in the cloud forest of Costa Rica ( Brown et al. 2018 ). The diversity found at that spot is probably much higher, considering the short sampling period of only one year and the fact that specimens were presorted in the same way as described here (see the section on material and methods). Assuming that our estimates are close to reality, about 95 percent of the species existing in the world remain uncollected and unnamed. At the same time, our knowledge of the named species is fragmentary, and provisional insofar as the status of many names published after 1970 remains unclear. Given this actual situation, almost 170 years after the first
Winnertzia
species was published, one might begin to wonder how research into the diversity and taxonomy of
Winnertzia
will proceed in the future.

The vital point here is the question of motive. Unless there is an institutional agenda that determines the research objectives (as in the case of our project), any progress with
Winnertzia
will depend on the interests and preferences of individual researchers. Who will decide whether investigating the life history of
Winnertzia solidaginis
is more important than redescribing 50
Winnertzia
species from the ex-Soviet Union? Or, whether elucidating the phylogeny of
Winnertzia
is more urgent than exploring the taxonomic merit of larval structures? In the absence of any overarching strategy for the future, all contributions should be welcomed in equal measure, on condition that they result from bonafide, methodologically sound research. Obviously, there is no shortage of unworked scientific issues relating to
Winnertzia
(see Introduction). Considering the generally poor knowledge of species distributions, even faunal lists – often dismissed as trivial – can add important pieces of information. As mentioned in the introduction, the present study is a contribution to the Swedish Taxonomy Initiative (STI), a governmental venture aimed at completing the inventory of all multicellular life found in Sweden ( Ronquist 2010 ). A laborious survey like ours would probably never have happened without STI’s mission and funding. The fact that initiators like STI are nonexistent in most other parts of the world makes one wonder whether individual passion and funds will suffice to shed light on the diversity of
Winnertzia
in the Sahara Desert, the Himalaya, or the Valdivian Temperate Forest (this list of blank areas for
Winnertzia
may be extended at will). “At root, the problems are more political and sociological than scientific”, wrote Wheeler (2004: 571) some time ago on the decline of what he calls the real taxonomy, and we agree with him.

As regards the issue of
Winnertzia
identification, the present study has made clear that the diagnostic potential of male morphological indicators decreases dramatically in situations where too many largely similar species are involved, as in the species complex around
Winnertzia solidaginis
. Likewise, we are sceptical towards the efficiency of male morphology when it comes to cope with the entirety of
Winnertzia
in Europe or the Palearctic region. Promising other sources of diagnostic characters are the morphology of females and COI sequence (DNA barcoding) data. A case in point is that the ovipositor of
Winnertzia
is more complex, and thus more informative for taxonomy, than that of most other mycophagous cecidomyiids. The difficulty with females is that, morphologically, they are hard to match to conspecific males, unless one can draw on specimens reared from the same pool of larvae. The usefulness of COI sequence data combined with male morphological indicators is beyond doubt, but the building of a DNA barcode library – the basis for positive identification – is for
Winnertzia
in the very early stages. We regard the body of COI sequence data generated in the course of our project as too incipient for release here (but intend its publication at a more advanced stage of our investigations), because only a small proportion of our DNA barcodes can at present be related to valid species names. While recognizing the advantages of a complete DNA barcode library for
Winnertzia
, with the inclusion of the species named in the past, we are under no illusion as regards the magnitude of this task (see the remarks on the rare-species-problem in the introduction). Therefore, we fully expect that, for years to come, male morphology will play the lead in taxonomic decisions concerning
Winnertzia
, merely and simply because additional kinds of evidence are unavailable for comparative analysis.
